title: 113_hr5470
content: The "Visa Waiver Program Improvement Act of 2014" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 discusses grounds for ineligibility for travel to the United States, reports on law enforcement and security interests, continuing qualification and designation terminations, and a report on strengthening the electronic system for travel authorization. The Visa Waiver Program Improvement Act of 2014 discusses grounds for ineligibility for travel to the United States, including terrorism risk. Amendments are made to Section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding security and terrorism risks. The Secretary may limit the period of eligibility for travel. Additional reports on limitations are required. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report annually on individuals denied travel eligibility under the Visa Waiver Program, in consultation with the Secretary of State. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report annually on individuals denied travel eligibility under the Visa Waiver Program, in consultation with the Secretary of State. Additionally, individuals whose eligibility for travel was revoked due to representing a threat to the security of the United States will be reported periodically. Homeland Security, in consultation with the Director of National Intelligence, must submit a threat assessment report to relevant congressional committees regarding foreign governments' compliance with specified agreements. This amends subsection (c) of section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Amendment to section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act includes changes to committee names and subclauses in subparagraph (A)(i). The amendment to section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act includes changes to committee names and subclauses in subparagraph (A)(i), as well as the addition of a new clause regarding program suspension authority for countries in the visa waiver program. The amendment to section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act grants the Secretary of Homeland Security the authority to suspend a country from the visa waiver program without prior notice, notify the suspended country with justification, and restore participation upon compliance. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, must submit a report on strengthening the Electronic System for Travel Authorization within 30 days of the Act's enactment to enhance border security and prevent terrorism. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, must submit a report on strengthening the Electronic System for Travel Authorization within 30 days of the Act's enactment to enhance border security and prevent terrorism. The first report required under section 217(c)(5)(A)(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act shall be submitted at the same time as the next report after the date of the enactment of this Act.
